description: Music & Pop Culture - Songs, Artists & Lyrics

phrases.note: The verb 'sÅ‚uchaÄ‡' (to listen) takes the genitive case, so 'muzyki' (music) is in genitive.
A common word for a music group. Plural is 'zespoÅ‚y'.
Use 'piosenkarz' for male, 'piosenkarka' for female. The root 'piosenka' means 'song'.
A general term for someone who plays music. Plural is 'muzycy'.
Pronounced similarly to English. It's a masculine noun.
Can refer to a vinyl record ('pÅ‚yta winylowa') or a CD ('pÅ‚yta CD').
A feminine noun. 'Chwytliwa melodia' means 'catchy tune'.
A masculine noun. Pronounced 'ritm'.
Literally 'What music pleases you?'. 'Ci' is the dative form of 'ty' (you).
Pronounced as in English. It's an indeclinable noun.
Pronounced as in English. Also indeclinable.
Pronounced as in English. Indeclinable.
Short for 'muzyka klasyczna' (classical music). 'Klasyczna' is the feminine adjective.
Both terms are commonly used and understood.
Short for 'muzyka elektroniczna' (electronic music). 'Elektroniczna' is the feminine adjective.
Pronounced as in English. Indeclinable.
Pronounced as in English. Indeclinable.
'Folk' is a direct borrowing, 'ludowa' means 'folk/traditional' (from 'lud' - people).
'Ulubiony' (favorite) is an adjective that agrees in gender and number. Here, masculine singular.
'Ulubiona' (favorite) is feminine singular, agreeing with 'piosenka' (song).
'Åšwietna' means 'great' or 'excellent'. It's a feminine adjective.
'Znam' is 'I know' (a person, a song, a place). 'TÄ™' is the accusative feminine form of 'ta' (this).
An imperative form. 'Ze mnÄ…' means 'with me' (instrumental case).
'PolskÄ…' is the accusative feminine form of 'polski' (Polish), agreeing with 'muzykÄ™'.
One of the most popular contemporary Polish pop-rock singers.
A very popular young Polish singer-songwriter known for pop and indie music.
A highly influential and popular Polish rapper.
An iconic Polish singer and composer, active from the 1960s, known for his unique style.
A popular genre of Polish dance music, often associated with weddings and parties.
Pronounced as in English. Indeclinable.
'ÅšpiewaÄ‡' is the infinitive 'to sing'.

'PoleciÄ‡' is a perfective verb meaning 'to recommend'. 'Polskej muzyki' would be genitive if asking for 'some' Polish music.
Literally 'text of the song'. 'Piosenki' is genitive singular of 'piosenka'.
A masculine noun. Pronounced 'ref-ren'.
A feminine noun. Pronounced 'zvrot-ka'.
A direct borrowing from English, commonly used.
'PrzebÃ³j' is the native Polish word for 'hit song' or 'blockbuster'. It's a masculine noun.
A masculine noun. 'IÅ›Ä‡ na koncert' (to go to a concert) takes the accusative case.
'IdÄ™' is 'I go/I'm going'. 'Na koncert' means 'to a concert'.
'Bilety' is plural for 'ticket'. 'Na koncert' specifies the purpose.
'Muzyczny' is the masculine adjective for 'music', agreeing with 'festiwal'.
A feminine noun. Used for a concert stage or theater stage.
A feminine noun. Refers to the collective group of spectators.

phrases.pl: Jaki jest twÃ³j ulubiony gatunek muzyki?
phrases.note: 'Gatunek' (genre) is masculine. 'Muzyki' (of music) is genitive.
'UtwÃ³r' is a more general term for a musical piece, composition, or track, compared to 'piosenka' (song).
'Ma' means 'he/she has'. 'GÅ‚os' (voice) is masculine. 'Åšwietny' (great) agrees with 'gÅ‚os'.
'Teksty' (lyrics) is plural. 'GÅ‚Ä™bokie' (deep) is the plural adjective.
'Chwytliwa' (catchy) is a feminine adjective, agreeing with 'melodia'.
An imperative. 'GÅ‚oÅ›niej' is the comparative form of 'gÅ‚oÅ›no' (loudly).
An imperative. 'ÅšciszyÄ‡' is a perfective verb meaning 'to quiet down/turn down'.
'ZmieniÄ‡' is a perfective verb meaning 'to change'. 'PiosenkÄ™' is accusative.

phrases.en: I'm putting on my favorite playlist.
phrases.note: 'PuszczaÄ‡' means 'to let go/play'. 'PlaylistÄ™' is accusative feminine.
'Klasyk' is a masculine noun, referring to a classic piece of art, music, or literature.
'Nowy' (new) is a masculine adjective, agreeing with 'album'.
A feminine noun, used for the first public showing or release of something.
Literally 'star of pop'. 'Popu' is genitive of 'pop'.
Plural of 'fan'. Pronounced 'fah-nee'.
A masculine noun. Can refer to a musical, theatrical, or other type of performance.
A masculine noun. A common term for a music video.
A direct borrowing, commonly used.
A direct borrowing, commonly used.
'GraÄ‡ na' (to play an instrument) takes the locative case. 'JakimÅ›' means 'some/any'.
A complete sentence to state your favorite song. 'Moja' (my) is feminine.
'Åšpiewam' is 'I sing'. 'Pod prysznicem' (under the shower) uses the instrumental case.

phrases.en: It's on the tip of my tongue.
phrases.note: An idiom, literally 'I have it on the end of my tongue'. Used when you almost remember something.
'WzruszaÄ‡' means 'to move/touch emotionally'. 'Mnie' is the accusative form of 'ja' (I).
'RozÅ›mieszaÄ‡' means 'to make laugh'. 'Mnie' is the accusative form of 'ja' (I).
'UspokajaÄ‡' means 'to calm down'. 'Mnie' is the accusative form of 'ja' (I).
'MotywowaÄ‡' means 'to motivate'. 'Mnie' is the accusative form of 'ja' (I).
'Artysta' (artist) is masculine. 'Ulubiony' (favorite) agrees with it.

phrases.en: Where can I listen to this song?
phrases.note: 'PosÅ‚uchaÄ‡' is the perfective form of 'sÅ‚uchaÄ‡'. It takes the genitive case ('tej piosenki').
Common platforms. 'Na' (on) takes the locative case, but for proper nouns like these, they are often used as is.
'ÅšciÄ…gnÄ…Ä‡' is a perfective verb meaning 'to download'. 'PiosenkÄ™' is accusative.
'StrumieniowaÄ‡' is a verb meaning 'to stream'. 'MuzykÄ™' is accusative.
'Na Å¼ywo' means 'live' (as in, not recorded).
'Wyprzedane' is the past participle, meaning 'sold out' (plural, agreeing with 'bilety').
A masculine noun. 'PoprosiÄ‡ o autograf' (to ask for an autograph).
'Winylowa' is the feminine adjective for 'vinyl', agreeing with 'pÅ‚yta'.
A plural noun. Always used in plural form.
A masculine noun. Plural is 'gÅ‚oÅ›niki'.
A masculine noun. Can refer to a single sound or the general concept of sound.
A masculine noun, referring to the person who writes lyrics.
A masculine noun. Feminine form is 'kompozytorka'.
'Muzyczny' (musical) is an adjective agreeing with 'producent'.
'NagrywaÄ‡' is an imperfective verb meaning 'to record'. 'PiosenkÄ™' is accusative.
Literally 'studio of recordings'. 'NagraÅ„' is genitive plural of 'nagranie' (recording).
